text: One of my early memories is my grandfather calling us on the landline phone one morning to tell my mom they're playing it on one TV channel and to put it on for me to see... Beautiful film

It seems even in the 1960s the food and water in large parts of Mexico were effectively poisonous for outsiders and would either make you very sick or straight up kill you if you consumed them. Water was full of tropical diseases and parasites that locals had become resistant to.

Arthur Jones said he knew some rural Mexican who had 24 live children born and only like 6 of them made it out of early infancy. You either died of infections or survived and were immune to the food and water afterwards... Broda Banres described something similar in his book too.

That Dr. Ray Peat radio show where he talked about his early childhood reading "Smokey Stover" comics and the "Little Blue Books" and going to a rural "One-room school" shows just how different society was. Look at the Smokey Stover comics panels. It's a completely alien culture.

People'll joke about how "everyone is an American now", but if you read about culture and life in the USA during the Great Depression era and the 40s, it actually seems more alien than anything in 19th or 20th century Europe. It's a completely alien society unlike anything today.
Esoteric (non-Mexican) South American alcohols mentioned
This time "esoteric" in the literal sense of traditional initiation like straight out of a Rene Guenon book

Shot putters are some of the freakiest athletes ever. Look up "shot put hand", their throwing hands become mutated looking just from the mechanical stress. You can find videos of shot put pros like Ryan Crouser training and they are insanely explosive on bench press, cleans, etc.
Shot put should be in the same category as powerlifting and Olympic weightlifting it's straight up a strength sport
Shot put

You can see how some people (obviously mostly women, especially somewhat older and unhappier) can get addicted to this feeling to the point of actually developing psychosomatic "Functional Neurological Disorder" of the Long Covid/Fibromyalgia/Chronic Lyme/Havana Syndrome variety.

Not that some of the above are not also "real" conditions or that psychosomatic disease is "fake". But also sometimes as a child when you really want to skip school due to some stressful exam or whatever you do actually fall sick with a fever and such. There's never hard borders.
Generally most doctors with a lot of clinical experience have very good reasons to be so skeptical but when they are wrong it's very frustrating for the patient
Exactly, at the end of the day it makes little difference practically if it's some bizarre idiopathic thing or psychological if it's treated the same way with the thyroid-steroids-vitamins type stuff

I would assume the film people probably talk about this a lot, but the fact that "The Wizard of Oz" film from the 1930s somehow looks better than any single normie movie produced today is just such an objective sign of cultural degeneration that you simply cannot hide in any way.

With decline of living standards, health, education, and the food supply you can endlessly hide behind technological progress and various statistical trickery, but here it's just so naked. You put the film from a century ago to whatever new movie and it'll make it look like shit.

I like Wes Anderson and know nothing whatsoever about filming as an art form but I think you can tell it's something recent, I don't watch more than one movie per year but I feel like you can easily tell it just looks different in a fundamental way. Film guys can 100% easily tell

Also even if I know nothing whatsoever about anything related to film as an art form as to make predictions, you can bet the AI people are going to attempt to use AI to make the new movies visually look like the Wizard of Oz and it's going to just make the entire affair more sad.

There was a crazy health blogger who I think nuked his online presence who believed that sleeping upside down like a vampire caused the heart muscle to stretch in an unusual way from the gravity making it produce some anti-aging peptides and attributed some bats' longevity to it.
